title: Spanish grassroots football to lose 53 million euros a month due to coronavirus pandemic
text:
Spanish grassroots football to lose 53 million euros a month due to coronavirus pandemic Spanish Football According to a study

The economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic sweeping the globe will hit Spanish football at all levels, not just the highest.

Now, a study has found that the impact on amateur and youth football could be as much as 53 million euros lost each month.

The study by Amedeo Spadaro, an economics professor at the University of the Balearic Islands, shows the operating costs which have been paralysed without any revenue due to the COVID-19 crisis.

He concludes that "the best thing is to end the season to cushion the impact of the crisis."

He points out that amateur football clubs all over the country suffer from "an absolute lack of income", and he compares it to the situation that most small and medium sized companies are suffering from.

The UIB economics professor points to the fact that clubs do not have income from fees and tickets, but they are obliged to pay the total cost of salaries, including net salaries, social security, allowances and maintenance costs of the facilities.

He stresses, in that context, 'the uncertainty over the duration of this situation' and the 'total absence of parachute mechanisms,' since 'neither the Spanish government nor the Spanish Football Federation (RFEF) have made the slightest mention of the economic damage caused by coronavirus to football.'

Spadaro cites official data from the Higher Sports Council (CDS) to put the number of federated clubs in Spain at 21,200, with an average of around 50 licences per club.

"From a quick economic estimate, the average club in Spain (50 salaries) faces total monthly activity costs of approximately 2,500 euros. This means that, every month, amateur football is losing 53 million euros," the economist emphasises.

In order to 'minimise' the losses, and in view of 'the uncertainty about the duration of the pandemic', Spadaro believes that the RFEF 'should now declare the 2019/2020 season over'.

"Such a measure would allow clubs to reduce costs almost definitively, and would also allow all football, not just amateur football, to benefit from emergency closures and, eventually, to apply for aid and compensation from the public authorities", he says.

The monthly economic cost for the two autonomous federations with the largest number of licences, Catalonia and Madrid, would amount to 8,578,293 and 5,971,741 euros, respectively.

According to the study by Amedeo Spadaro, the figures per region would be: Andalusia, 7,855,550 euros; Aragon, 1,588,270; Asturias, 1,297,916; the Canary Islands, 2,391,777; Cantabria, 743,931; Castile and Leon, 2,277,062; Castile-La Mancha, 2,152,575; Community of Valencia, 5,130,095; Galicia, 4,810,626; Murcia, 2,356,580; Navarra, 825,344,; Basque Country, 3,650,757; La Rioja, 387,370; Ceuta, 125,583, and Melilla, 147,669.
